Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: threat or non-threat. Threatening someone means implying that someone will be hurt even if they do not do something specific.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: He should be executed, not given 48 years.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Opening up people of a different race to violent acts including death by idiots, by inciting her followers to violence, is offensive. If anything happens to the Jones family, Dembroski should be charged as an accessory.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat to anyone.

I also acknowledge how difficult it must have been for you to admit I might have superior knowledge about anything, in contrast to your half-baked and purportedly omniscient stereotypying of nearly everything.  I hope that superficial act of humility was not too painful for your otherwise impervious sense of self-certitude:)  So I'll finish in kind, by paraphrasing Shakespeare: First, we kill all the lawyers. Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: "who do you think should do the killing?"

Anyone and everyone. This is a community problem, so everyone who wants to be part of the solution should be allowed to help. As I said above: remove all protections on free ranging cats, and allow people to help. People who allow their pets to roam outside are part of the problem, because their pets are part of the problem. It would be very sad if pets were killed, but ultimately it is the owner's responsibility to make sure their pets are not out killing birds.

Years ago some Vermont acquaintances got one warning from the Ranger: Next time I see your dog running deer, I'll shoot it. Next time she saw it running deer, she did. 

Vermont does not pretend that trapping, neutering, and releasing dogs solves any problems. They are serious about threats. We just want to feel good about ourselves. If we were serious about feral cats, we would kill them. Neutered cats eat birds. Don't release them. Kill them.

Comment: The Eugene city government is not serious about solving the problem of homelessness. In spite of the success of the rest stops, there still are a lot of people who don't qualify for the programs . The city had six months to approve a site for the Nightingale site, but hasn't approved one yet. Fortunately, the Eugene Mission extended their stay there for a couple of months so the weather will at least be better when they are forced to move.
The requirement that legal rest stops must be run by a non-profit organization keeps many people from being able to set up and run their own camps, and guarantees that there will be many homeless people who won't have legal places to stay.
Both the rest stops and the dusk to dawn sites require people to leave during the day. Neither of these programs alleviate the problem of homeless people not having places to exist during the day, so there will always be complaints about the number of them downtown, at the library, etc.

  Reducing the Transmission of Blood-Borne Viral Infections & Other Injection Related Infections

Comment: Balto, if all the people (and businesses) currently paying insurance premiums paid those into the single-payer system as (gasp!) taxes, that must be enough to pay for all the medical care (for reasons below). 

1. This new system would have negotiating power with which to drive down pharmaceutical prices and eliminate other excessive costs. 

2. Preventive care is often less expensive than acute care, and if everyone were covered, preventive care would be much more likely. 

3. No insurance company advertising costs, excessive administration, profits, etc.

4. If everybody else in the world can do it (that is, cover everyone with better care at lower per-person cost), why can't we? Are we stupid? 

But you raise a legitimate question: If people are ideologically opposed to taxes -- and would rather have a screwed-up system with high premiums, inadequate coverage, many people not covered at all, etc. -- then what can we do? Not much. 

But claiming that we can't afford it is hogwash.

Comment: I don't believe the progressivity would have been a factor under current oil prices to help the state coffers. Main components of SB21 over ACES:
- Increases the base tax rate from 25% to 35%
- Eliminates progressivity 
- Eliminates a 20% capital investment tax credit for North Slope investment (including maintenance)
- Replaces the capital investment credit with a per-barrel production tax credit that only kicks in when a company actually increases production rather than just spends money
- New fields outside existing producing fields, the per-barrel tax credit is $5. A sliding scale based on the price of oil applies to existing fields. The credit begins at $8 per barrel at lower oil prices ($90 per barrel) and falls to zero at high prices ($150 per barrel)
- New North Slope oil fields qualify for a Gross Revenue Exclusion (GRE) that exempts 20% of new oil from the base tax rate

Comment: Bob-thank you for the kind words.  Unfortunately, fund balances are not the result of intentionally collecting more taxes while knowing that expenses will be a lesser amount. Fund balances grow when warm winters resulting in less spent on snow removal and heating costs than budgeted, or because an entity experiences increased employee attrition.  Fund balances are not the result of simply asking for money than expected need.  Financial plans require expenditures to equal revenues, so in essence, a spending cap already exists with the current tax cap.

A new, unnecessary spending cap encourages short term waste of fund balances as government pumps up budgeted spending levels, using fund balances as a revenue source to enhance the level of future spending cap calculations.  I know that's not the intent, but that's what will happen.

Comment: Oh man I remember Mom and her spring cleaning. What chaos. And it made Mom happy, she'd just scrub and work all day for a week. Mom figured if you used a mop you were just pushing the dirt around so it all had to be done on hands and knees. Water had to be pumped from a pitcher pump and dirty water had to be carried out to the 'slop pile'. ( Guess who got to do those little tasks?) She didn't just clean, she literally sanitized every square inch of that 2 story log house. Every stick of furniture had to be moved and "Why not re-arrange while we're at it?"  Curtains had to be taken down and washed and all linens hung on the clothesline "to get rid of the woodsmoke smell." She even had the barrel stove put outside for the summer. We could never find anything after she finished.  All our gloves and mitts were gone from the pile behind the stove. The place reeked of Clorox and Pine-sol and Fels-Naptha soap.
Worst part was she didn't stop to bake cookies when she was in "cleaning mode".

Comment: We have some points of agreement. However, the attractions of Eugene for homeless people are difficult to stop from occurring (several free meals per day, free laundry service, free clothes, no enforcement of camping/drinking/drug laws, no enforcement of parking laws). In fact, judges far-removed from the impact of the worst of the homeless population on communities are taking away civic tools that have previously been used to drive homeless people elsewhere. 

Pragmatically, we can whine about that or find solutions that benefit our city. If we use public resources to help the homeless people who would be inclined to participate positively to get back up, then we can turn our attention to more punitive measures for the people who just want to trash our public spaces while getting intoxicated. If we use public resources to provide a safety net to people who are on the verge of homelessness, then we won't have to spend money helping them recover in the first place.

Comment: The concept of mixing affordable housing with  "upscale" units in the same complex , IMO, simply doesn't make sense.  Whether we like it or not, such divergent social/economic classes do not "mix well" as neighbors.  Additionally, those upscale developments are far more expensive to build and require higher rents to be a viable investment.  I would suggest that, instead, a developer of such an upscale project be required to, at the same time, build a specified number of affordable units (maybe 25% or whatever)...BUT NOT IN THE SAME DEVELOPMENT.  A developer could build them, then if he/she didn't wish to own/manage working-class affordable housing, sell them to someone who did.  The idea of a forced mixing of two very different housing niches simply doesn't make sense to me. It smacks of "social engineering".....very bad social engineering.   Gary Crum

Comment: I'm inclined to agree. When I was a kid, we had only three TV channels, no internet, and our friends were real. Perhaps more important, what we saw was real, too. No carefully tailored online personas making us feel inadequate because our lives weren't as cool as theirs. No "likes" or other reactions to judge the worthiness of our thoughts, just face-to-face feedback. That can be really negative too, but at least you can escape it by going home.
Social media has its place -- it can be very useful, especially during times of emergency -- but using it to judge yourself is like comparing your life to a TV show. No one is as cool as the Fonz (no matter what their fb page says), so you're not a loser if you aren't either.

Comment: In 2000, we voters in Oregon limited our Police in doing this.   It was an Initiative, of course.

https://ballotpedia.org/Oregon_Property_Forfeiture_Requirements,_Measure_3_(2000)

Oregon Measure 3 (2000)

  Yes  952,792  67.20%

  No  465,081  32.80%

In Oregon our greedy police agencies then had to "prove by the stricter standard of clear and convincing evidence that the property was used to commit, or was the proceeds of, the crime for which the owner was convicted. If the person whose property was seized is not charged or convicted of a crime, the property must be returned unless the property has been abandoned or is contraband."  

Now it takes proof beyond a reasonable doubt to forfeit property.

https://www.oregonlaws.org/ors/2009/131.582

Comment: Nobody - because I said nothing about ideas being tolerable. I spoke of ideas being tolerANT or not. And that is an extremely easy thing to determine. I must tolerate your views even if I disagree with them - as long as you do the same for me. If your view is that I should be cut into tiny little pieces and fed to the dogs, I'm not obligated to tolerate that view. If your view is that I should not be allowed to express my views - then I'm not obligated to tolerate that view and I am justified to prevent you expressing it so that all the many other views can remain safe to express.

Comment: We should cut corporate taxes but how much given the deficit. We need tax cuts that get growth in the economy through raises or hiring ASAP-- we need more consumer spending to generate more investment. Raises are the more important tool now than hiring since we are now at full employment. What we need now is to grow consumption to stimulate production of finished and component goods and that will stimulate more corporate investment with cash they already have. Besides raises, tax cuts for the middle class which accounts for 70% of consumer spending are another way to gain immediate growth and stimulate production of more goods. Corporations are doing well and many are flush with cash already 
and adding more cash will take a huge tax cut down below 15% because corporations effectively pay at the 15% rate. Corporations will spend cash now first to enhance stock value by buybacks and distributions to shareholders before more investment (they are saying so) vs more efficient tax cuts.

Comment: "The bill overhauled a state hospital funding program and rewrote the state‚Äôs pot tax law, eliminating a 2.9 percent tax on recreational pot in favor of an increase in the special sales tax on marijuana from 10 to 15 percent. "
I understand the fix to hospital funding, moving co-mingled state & federal funds meant to be a pass-through out from under TABOR. 
But I don't see why the rewrite of pot tax law, which eliminated one tax and imposed another, was not required by TABOR to be placed before the voters in the first place. Though I agree that if it didn't in May, then it doesn't now. 
As for the special session, it's a win-win for the governor. If they fix the problem, he's a hero for calling the session. If they don't, he gets to blame those obstructing Republicans. A nice result after signing the flawed bill in the first place. 
There's plenty of blame to go around for allowing the initial error through, including the special districts themselves as I understand the process.

Comment: In response to Alceste.

I agree Naddway's comments are in poor taste but they are neither racist nor misogynistic.  Just because you don't like something, that doesn't give you the right to abuse the English language by applying meaning to something that doesn't exist.

For the record the definitions are:
Racism: prejudice, discrimination, or antagonism directed against someone of a different race based on the belief that one's own race is superior. 

Misogyny: dislike of, contempt for, or ingrained prejudice against women.

Now, I am not saying he or she is neither of these things, but your incorrect application of these words is such as to cause epistemological problems of sufficient magnitude as to lay upon the logical and semantic resources of the English language a heavier burden than they can reasonably be expected to bear.

Comment: Family health history and the desire to leave an estate are personal factors not considered in the analysis as it wasn't the point, but I would agree, for many those are often considerations.  That said, creating an estate with the proceeds of a RIF or RSP upon death is probably one of the worst ways to do it as the last to die will be subject to a larger final tax hit, which will ultimately be paid by the heirs.  But, if you really want to go that route then you want to get the money out as quickly and efficiently as possible and into a TFSA.  Alternatively, you might consider life insurance if that is not an option.

Comment: Yup

....in late 2014, federal lawmakers responded to the dilemma in another way: They made it possible to cut retiree benefits. The Multiemployer Pension Reform Act, tucked into a huge omnibus spending bill and passed without public hearings or debate, set up a mechanism through which pension trustees could propose a plan to reduce monthly payments. Backed by a coalition of pension plan trustees, unions, and employers, this approach will stretch the dwindling assets of troubled funds further into the future. But for retirees, most of whom knew little or nothing about the change in law as it was happening, it means benefits they earned could go up in smoke.

Comment: People go right to "free stuff" when they hear "Socialist".  That is because the word "free" is attached to things like "free college". 
Of course it's not "free". Instead the revenue is collected from the people to pay for things the people then benefit from. 
For example, I get "free" fire protection, sidewalks, streetlights, policing, among others. I get a subsidized college tuition, but 80% of it comes out of my pocket. Since I can't afford college, I work in a low-paying job, get food stamps, maybe subsidized housing. More socialism.
Now, when everyone chips in and my college is paid for, I feel in high school that good grades is all I need. I get a college degree. Make more money. Pay more taxes. Avoid social services. Even our balance of trade is better. Everyone benefits. So why shouldn't everyone pay?
When you think of it, if I pay for college and pay more taxes, the people who benefit are getting free ride on my prosperity. What is fair about that?

If any sentence you have written recently demonstrates the tenuous grasp on policy you exhibit, this must be it. What Dodd-Frank has accomplished is the acceleration of the growth of the size of the banking industry. This growth has been fueled by the consolidation of banks into even bigger behemoths, & a substantial decrease in smaller, community banks who cannot afford to comply with the drastic regulatory costs. Comment: OK, one more post, then it's on to the research. I believe Tier 1 for new hires ended at the end of 1995. I found that there are still over 34,000 active Tier 1 employees. That's a lot of people. It definitely is not fair to say to them "We promised too much" but by the time the last Tier 1 employee retires, we might wish the state had said "We promised too much, and if you want anything at all, you'll need to expect a little less". Never happen, I know, but we're staring a major funding crisis in the face, not tomorrow, but right now. It's unimaginable what Oregon will look like by 2025 if PERS keeps gobbling up tax dollars at the rate it is.

Comment: Kaepernick certainly is fighting for his country. Is that what you mean? He's currently unemployable, being willing to sacrifice his livelihood for his beliefs. Isn't that sort of heroic? 

People join the military for all sorts of reasons. Black folks joined during the Civil War to fight slavery. Frederick Douglass saw military service, incorrectly it turned out, as a claim for full citizenship for black men. For many poor people, the military is a way out of the impossible circumstances in which they were born and grew up.

Comment: When I was ordained 50+ years ago I enjoyed being called "Father" and always wearing the collar. Later I entered active duty as an Army Chaplain, rarely wore the collar, and learned to be called "Chaplain", and often just my first name. While it took some getting used to, I liked it, and I still do. I spent most of my years as a priest on active duty or connected to the Army. For many of those years as well as after retirement, I have also been called by my street name and call sign, "Frog", and I enjoy this a lot. It cuts through a lot of protocol. In the Army I had a responsibility just like everyone else in uniform, and "Chaplain" recognized that. I don't have to be called by a special title to help folks however I can. Crawling through mud and being afraid is a great equalizer. I am on the same journey as everybody else, we are all equal, and we help each other. I have been Jim longer that I have been "Father", and I have earned "Frog". I like this. IOW, I agree with Bill.

Comment: One of the underlying assumptions of peace movements appears to be that peace is the natural state of human affairs and conflict is a departure from the norm. A variety of ancient myths point to an original state of harmony violated by human initiative. From this perspective, we may find it difficult to understand why peace is so elusive, when it should be so easy to return to our natural state.
Science points to a perspective that may help us understand the human condition. The natural state of any object is actually one of dynamic tension and at least implicit conflict. We all know Newton's Third Law of  Motion (every action has an equal and opposite reaction) and understand that all of us are constantly exerting force against everything else, which means we're actually competing with one another. In this view, peace is the elusive goal, and conflict the abiding reality. That may be hard to accept, but it helps explain why things are as they are, and why peace doesn't come naturally.

Comment: Fortunately for many many reasons, the USA is just one country in a wide world. Stuff like your EWTN need to be kept in proportion.

Whether the Mass is in Latin or any other language should reflect the needs of parishes.  Treating this kind of thing as a quasi-political demarcation line is distasteful at very least. Weaponising  the Mass verges on  sacrilege.

In many of our churches English, or whatever the language of the country we live in, is not in fact our native tongue. A vernacular Mass is a foreign language Mass - it might as well be Latin.  

Having separate Masses in other languages is one way to deal with this. Our parish has a Polish Mass. But that means a divided community, and does nothing for those from other countries.

A regular Latin Mass for all every few weeks would be a sensitive way of reflecting that, and bringing us together.

And all this should have no connection with appeasing the rare internal schismatics who resist Vatican II, and oppose Pope Francis.

Comment: I think you got that view from another G&M opinion piece I remember reading which, once again, wasn‚Äôt based on fact. Pipeline companies charge tolls to ship oil or gas and those tolls are mandated by the national regulator. Doesn‚Äôt have anything to do with the price of oil (so much for your Econ 101 tutorial). Here‚Äôs some more basic economics and energy knowledge for you, when Eastern Canada imports oil via ship (tidewater) that oil is based off Brent pricing. Brent oil currently trades at a ~$7 premium to WTI. Canadian oil is landlocked due to lack of infrastructure thus trades off WTI. So we sell our oil at a discount to WTI which trades at a discount to Brent because we can‚Äôt figure out how to build a pipeline. And Eastern Canada gets screwed with higher gasoline prices because they have to import more expensive oil priced off Brent. Educate yourself on the facts vs taking G&M opionion pieces at face value.

Comment: Hi lespark. Good question. Boots has the best answer: "It becomes stronger." In a democracy, majority rights without minority rights is equal to tyranny. The quality of our democracy is defined by the respect and tolerance that we give to our minorities. In this TMT case, the majority must grant the minority every opportunity to change their minds and see the issue from the minority's perspective. The minority has the responsibility to make the best possible case for their position. If their powers of persuasion are great and their logic and evidence are strong, they could become the majority.

Comment: It's completely bootless to try to convince or force electors to vote against their duty; these are the rules of the game.  And these particular electors...just look at those first two "smiles"...

The emerging picture is that Trump didn't expect to win, and lord knows he seemed to be trying the throw the election at several key moments---But his support base wouldn't let him, and now he's president of the most powerful country on earth.  It's clear he's following the Reagan model with his appointments, and we'll just have to wait and see what he'll do with the increased executive powers carved out by Reagan, Bush, Clinton, Dubya, and retained by Obama.  

It's important right now to step outside of the bipolar partisan mindset that is dominating political discourse right now, in the media and elsewhere---It's been used to con us out of our liberties up to this point and shouldn't go any further.  It's up to us to keep channels open and learn how to work with each other.

Comment: An excellent article. 
To it I will add that the present call by some young African students is most likely an expression of their experiences of being culturally marginalised in higher educational institutions, their epistemic exclusion from scientific curriculae by virtue of language and cultural beliefs, and the past political and ongoing socio-economic practices that suppress(ed) their parents' aspirations. John Mbiti (1969) describes a concept of reality in traditional African thought as being rooted in the past and present, with very little weight being put on the 'non-real' space of the future. If we understand our students to be trapped in this inter-generational time-based reality, our task is to engage them educationally in ways that challenges this notion, by creating experiences wherein they see immediate benefits to science-based interventions within their own communities. Experience, not abstract discourse, is going to change the course of our society.

Comment: Medicare like Social Security is intended for retirees.  You pay into the program while you are actively employed and when you reach 65 years of age you start to receive Medicare coverage.  However, the coverage is only for Part A.  If you want clinical coverage for minor health problems you pay for Part B or choose an Advantage offering from a private insurer.

To include immediate health insurance coverage under Medicare for active workers the whole program needs to be overhauled.  It's not impossible, but the payroll deductions would not be  affordable, in the hundreds and possibly over a thousand for spouse and children coverage.

Comment: There was no annexation of Crimea. The claim otherwise is more fake news, meant to hype people up into supporting a position that isn't grounded in reality, but stems from ulterior motives.
Crimea's democratically-elected government organized a referendum to rejoin Russia (as they'd been trying to do for over 25 years). After the referendum was successful, Crimea's government applied for accession to Russia. Crimea was an unbound region at that time, not a part of Ukraine, as Ukraine had ceased to exist as a legal or constitutional entity when its constitution was rendered null and void in February 2014 - meaning, there were no Ukrainian laws, and no Ukrainian territory.
The outcome of the Crimea referendum has been confirmed as authentic by over a half-dozen international pollsters, and Crimea has invited the UN to visit and witness the situation.
Listen to what former CIA agent Ray McGovern has to say about what happened in Ukraine, and Russia's response:
https://youtu.be/NeSfvA4cCtg

Comment: In the many "solutions" put forward, I notice many that are bludgeons, not scalpels, and will have painful unintended consequences. Take this one, which the Feds may be contemplating: "Raise the portion of profits subject to capital gains tax on sales of non-principal residences to deter speculation and flipping." Sounds good in the case of (foreign) buyers, who are here to make a quick buck, do their laundry, and get out. But ALL non-principal residences? Consider the fallout on non-principal residences owned by moms and pops who in good faith became small landlords 30 years ago as part of their retirement plans. Think of others like them who will sell and cease to provide rental space altogether. Think also of the multitude of developers who will stop building it. One can't expect rents to decrease in such a scenario, unless (as another commenter suggests), the years owned are recognized on a graduated scale. If government must meddle, surgical strikes are in order, not H-bombs.

Comment: We absolutely can and have changed the world's climate. That's not arrogance, it's measurable reality and recognition of human responsibility. What is arrogant is to believe we can fix it or that we will be clever enough to modify its effects so we can continue on our present course, or continue at all.

The Permian extinction, the largest mass extinction of life on earth - an estimated 95% of all life forms disappeared - is believed to have been caused by very long-term, massive volcanic action that put billions of tons of CO2 into the atmosphere and caused the oceans to turn highly acidic. Humans have done the same thing by burning fossil fuels. That is chemistry. The failure to anticipate or recognize the tragic consequences of human destruction is where the arrogance lies. We're very clever little monkeys when it comes to techno-magical machines, but we don't really understand our world or its life, and worse, we haven't cared.  That's the arrogance.

It probably was no coincidence that EWEB soon found itself in a financial pickle and that overnight the weatherization program was curtailed without soliciting public input. Even the Board did not know. I had called one who was unaware that it had happened!  And he was surprised that public mtg spaces were being phased out & EWEB library eliminated. The way of Gray. 

Weatherization has been a long time sacred cow. 2 long time staff, then retired, wrote a letter to the editor protesting that travesty. We made a mistake not informing them, EWEB said.  Hiring Roger Gray was the mistake.

Comment: There were new condos that were purchased by investors who rented them out, creating competition and allowing developers a quicker return on their money. There was the fear that governments would again extend rent controls (an earlier rent control was for buildings built before 1975).

Jump ahead to 2016. A booming real estate market had developers again interested in longer-term projects, maybe to sell units to potential landlords looking for an income stream (e.g. retiring baby boomers).  Even talk of rent controls by the government (not just NDP) will slam the brakes on these developments. A rolling rent control scheme (controlled only after 25 years) may be fair and predictable, but will not solve the immediate problem. Worse, most of the horror stories are from people living in units would not be under rent control anyway - townhouses, condo units owned by landlords with few units.

Comment: I had the privilege to backpack the Valley back in '87 and my partner and I climbed to the top of that boulder'd plug.  It was eerily "alive" with steam and the aroma of sulfur emanating from cracks and the boulders themselves were strangely unstable, as if they are constantly being jostled by unseen forces beneath.   The entire area was like a scene from the Jurassic, steam vents pluming on the sides of Mt. Trident, lenticular clouds morphing with glaciers sweeping down from the heights contrasting the barren landscape itself strewn with pieces of pumice that sometimes flew through the air, born on the wind's venturi effect in Katmai Pass.   It was a trek of a lifetime I'll never forget.

Comment: Lagging pay and less work is an indicator of a labour shortage which corporations use to try and gain a competitive advantage or at least to maintain a level playing field with their peer companies. 

It also means that taxpayers are increasingly underwriting the labour costs of corporations as many of their employees have to supplement their incomes with social supports to survive.

This is a further indication that strong corporate earnings in a globalized economy are not shared and tend to accrue at the top thus increasing the wealth gap.

It is time that the provincial governments increased the minimum wage and taxed away the cost of social supports.  This would only be mildly inflationary, would increase the amount of money in circulation, and over the long term be beneficial to both business and society.

Comment: To dissenters;  many who utilize shelters have paid taxes throughout their lives. As noted in the article this can even save money for the city in the long term, especially if it is ran for profit.

And yes, the transitional housing part should be for profit, it should not have time limits, it should not require 'graduation', and it should not distinguish between 'homeless people' and regular people. It should be available to anyone in need of it. It should only ask two questions; do you have rent and can you follow the rules? 

It should be a legitimate option on the table. We cannot say people "choose" to be homeless until we give them actual choices. Currently the rental market is monopolized by the concept of physical privacy. However, you can house 3-4 broke people in the same space as one well off person and make the same amount of money by recognizing that privacy is in fact non-essential. Of course breaking this monopoly potentially contradicts Dames interests elsewhere.

Comment: The CPI is a dysfunctional measure of cost-of-living changes, for which purpose the RPIJ is much more suitable. The RPIJ annual inflation rate was 1.5% in November, up from 1.3% in October. The difference between CPI and RPIJ inflation rates would be even more pronounced if stamp duty were included in the RPI/RPIJ, as even the failed Johnson report on UK consumer price indices indicated seemed logical. (Stamp duty in the UK is equivalent to land transfer taxes in Canada. In Scotland, the tax is now called Land and Buildings Transactions Tax (LBTT) and different rates apply.) The ONS now publishes a quarterly index for  stamp duty which showed a 4.4% annual inflation rate for 2016Q3 as opposed to 4.0% for 2016Q2. Unfortunately, the ONS intends to discontinue the RPIJ after its January update, a strange fate for an index that was only introduced in March 2013, as a brilliant step forward from what had gone before, which it was.

Comment: At least some locations in Canada do indeed have a regional government sandwiched between the Provincial and Municipal level.  We have one here in the Kitchener-Waterloo area where there is the Waterloo Regional government in addition to the various city governments (Waterloo, Kitchener, Cambridge, etc.).

That does give us 4 levels of government, though thankfully the Region and City work pretty closely together (eg. I pay just one property tax bill that gets split between region and city).

K-W isn't unique here either, places like Peel and York (both with over a million people living in them) are in the same boat. I'm not sure if this is an Ontario-specific thing or if a similar setup exists in other Provinces.

‚óè appointment of the state‚Äôs presidential electors by the Governor and his Council, 
‚óè appointment by both houses of the state legislature, 
‚óè popular election using special single-member presidential-elector districts, 
‚óè popular election using counties as presidential-elector districts, 
‚óè popular election using congressional districts,

The Church has only been pro-immigrant when it suited is aims.   During the 1800s, the Church was all for the immigration of European Catholics to America.   The reason why is the same reason for why the Church today is pro immigration from Latino countries.   In a word, power.   

Large scale immigration in the 1800s led to Catholicism going from a very marginal and hated religion, to the U.S.'s largest and most powerful religion.   

The bishops know the awesome political power of immigration.

Comment: "...you end up with nothing to show for it."

I disagree. Take an extreme case: I give you $1M and a choice of either 1) buying my house from me for $1M or 2) renting it from me for $100/month. Hopefully it's clear that even parking that $1M in a savings account at today's criminally low rates generates more than enough return to cover your annual shelter costs (including annual rent increases). Now imagine that you diversely invested that $1M instead - including in real estate holdings, if you were so-inclined. You would be debt free, portable, and have a growing net worth while also being able to take care of your shelter needs (heck, you could buy a parcel of land somewhere less expensive if you wanted a "roof over your head" back-up plan). 

The reality in places like the Lower Mainland isn't THAT extreme, but for many thinking people starting out today, the choice to rent over owning isn't about being poor; it's about sound financial analysis.

Comment: The article's assertion that rotenone kills only fish is not true. Your assertion that rotenone can target ALL gill breathing life, including insects is also false. The response of aquatic invertebrates and amphibians to rotenone over the short- and long-terms is extremely well-studied. Rotenone kills SOME gill-breathing invertebrates, but many species and life history stages are invulnerable, especially with concentrations and durations applied in current practice. In reality, rotenone gives multivoltine invertebrates such as midges, blackflies, and Baetis mayflies a short-term advantage, as these invertebrates explode in biomass within weeks after rotenone treatment. Potassium permanganate is toxic, but for a duration, and it oxidizes rotenone within 30 minutes travel time. 

The prodigious ability of aquatic invertebrates to recolonize following disturbance has been known to science following seminal studies in the 1960s.

Comment: Skewed sample, partially, as it were. O stats!!  Much higher percentages of adherents have left other churches that permit policies that the CC doesn't permit. For example, according to Pew Researchers, the retention rates of Methodists and Pentecostals are 47%; Episcopalians, 45%; and Presbyterians, 40%. In raw numbers, of course, ex-Catholics are bound to be higher (since the CC is the largest church in US), but percentage-wise, its retention rate (60%) is a lot higher than most churches. If one factors into this mix converts (2.6  of all Americans) and immigrants (7.4%), the CC is relatively stable. Not surprisingly the Pew Report of 5/12/2015, notes that, precisely: "The estimate that the number of [adult] Catholics may have declined by as little as one million comes from subtracting the low end of the 2007estimate from the high end of the 2014 range."  Basic stats 101.

Many villages are beginning to go with renewables - there's always wind in the Y-K delta.  While not 100% reliable it's a start.  Yes, these may use some rare earth metals - less than you think - but there is definitely a net benefit overall.  

It won't be easy, fast, or smooth, but we are going there.   The car manufacturers are all over this - GM has pledged to go 100% electric or fuel cell, and others are right behind them.  They know what's coming...

Comment: I just read this article with great interest.  As an advocate for families with missing loved one, I wish this money could go into taking action now on the many recommendations already made in past inquiries and reviews.  I'd also like to inform the public that there are little or no supports for any families with missing loved ones.  I know this first hand when my son Daniel went missing in Nov. 2011.   

It's time for our country to develop a national Missing Persons framework (model) to support ALL families with missing loved ones, giving consistent supports, searches and investigations of ALL missing person cases.   Although the inquiry has implemented family liasion units, this is only for a number of identified families and only for the duration of the inquiry.  This is not enough.  A national Missing Persons framework would ensure that necessary supports and services are implemented and available to all families of missing loved ones.  Do you agree?

Comment: In reading the comments so far, I suspect that many may be missing the author's main point: the real intent of the mass.  I've actually heard many such definitions over my life, and some make me cringe.  I can live with the idea of "help[ing] form the participants into the Body of Christ."

That word "helping" is the right way to start thinking about this, as I see it.  I've long believed that what happens at the Mass is a lot less about what the priest does, as it is what WE do.  It may be hard to describe, but perhaps one facet of this is that we learn to see each other, not for where we are different, but for how we are alike.  We may be at many different levels in our faith development, but there is a commonality in that time next to each other: a sharing of what we are perhaps, or an acceptance of how we are part of something bigger, or maybe a chance to reach out to another.  The mass can be a lot of things, but a good place to start is to recognize what draws us together.

Comment: re: ZEVs wanted
" If you charge your car with electricity from a fossil fuel source, then it is not really a ZEV."
Even if you charge an electric car with "green" energy, it is not a ZEV.
There are emissions manufacturing it.  Mines and foundries, steel, petrochemical, and chemical plants, transportation of raw materials, sub-assemblies and parts, and transportation to retail outlets.
It's about time the life-cycle GHG emissions from manufacturing and operating electric vehicles and replacing their batteries every, say, six years was accounted for - as well as losses in electric transmission lines from the source.
And how does manufacturing, say, 3 ZEV's over 24 years compare with the life-cycle emissions of a single, mint, and well-maintained 24 year-old Suburban driven about 6,000 km/year?
For those of you really concerned about ZEVs, you should consider that a bicycle would be much better, but walking would be by far best.

Comment: As we watch Florida and Texas recover from the hurricanes, we should ask ourselves, what do we need to get our number one business, tourism, re-started if we have a high water event.  Tourists need room and board and electricity.  Would we be able to get these necessities going again if we were hit in any way by a high water event?  Among these three necessities, the most difficult would be water-out (toilets),  if our Sand Island Sewage Treatment facility was damaged.  If this facility is not working, Waikiki will have no tourists.  The problem is that this facility is only three feet above sea level.  Perhaps some of this money for Sewage Treatment should go to helping our major sewage treatment facility survive a high water event.

Comment: There was a study a couple of years back in The New England Journal of Medicine that showed the most cost effective medicine was provided by small practices, followed by large practices and finally by hospital owned practices. Obamacare and changes to Medicare, especially MACRA starting next year, have the effect of pushing physicians into larger and hospital owned practices. An architect of Obamacare recently admitted they were wrong on their thoughts on this in their design in a NYT article. MPFC does keep its Medicare and not all primary care clinics do. As someone in practice in Anchorage for 16 years (3 private) I have seen my patients age into Medicare and since I am alone in my specialty taking TRICARE because I think being a veteran means something. As a result I have watched my Medicare/TRICARE/Medicaid/VA get to be close to 50% of my practice. People forget that the margin is a lot lower for those of us not cherry picking the privately insured.

Comment: What Libby Unthank Tower advocates for is crucial, not least in light of what's happened to the rock 'n' roll bar scene in Eugene that produced the likes of the Searchin' Soul Blues Band in the late '60s and the Robert Cray Band and Curtis Salgado in the 1970s and how, according to Martin Scorsese, "Cinema is gone" (Register-Guard, 12/27, C4), for just two immediate examples. But it's also important to make explicit what Unthank Tower implies. For "culture" is not only music, books and our heritage. It is those patterns of meaning any group or society uses to interpret and evaluate itself and its situation. It is the symbolic and learned aspects of society transmitted not biologically but via social interaction. Nor can culture be reduced to, or explained away by, economic and political factor, though of course those factors certainly do influence -- without determining -- culture for good and ill, as Unthank Tower and the plight of rock 'n' roll and cinema demonstrate vividly.

Comment: This is an idea that has no merit.  Maine, Georgia, and Wyoming have such a rule today but there are no insurance companies interested.
1. An insurance company needs a provider network in that state so it must build one which is very expensive. Otherwise it cannot provide less expensive services.Starting without a customer base, what leverage is there to negotiate discounts from providers?
2. It needs a customer base to negotiate volume discounts from providers, so it must build one.
3. As a customer, why would one sign on with an insurance company if you don't know if your providers are in network?
4. This is a chicken and egg situation. For the insurance company  is this a productive use of its capital?
The idea sound good, the devil is in the details.

Now, since 2014 oil demand is growing again in the OECD countries wiping-out nearly two-thirds of the reduction between 2005 and 2014.

Demand for oil is growing again in the rich industrialized countries as cheaper oil means cheaper airfares and cheaper gasoline.

We are DECADES away from peak oil production.

Comment: Fracked oil from North Dakota peaked and declined deliberately because the world oil glut, which continues, took the oil price below the recovery cost. Every time oil goes above $50/bbl, the rigs start drilling, maintaining the glut. Why? because if drillers don't drill, they don't make money. It's as simple as that. But North Dakota has more than the Bakken, there are at least three equivalent shale formations below the Bakken, with equal prospects. The Williston Basin play can continue for at least another 50 years at near present capacity, along with other fields in the US, and there are numerous other oil shale basins around the world.

I'm not saying this would be a good thing, except for investors. I'm saying that as long as there is demand, oil will be around for the remainder of this century.

Comment: Risk - Substance abuse disorders

Some parents worry that their teens' use of cannabis can cause problems, and the report was mixed in its conclusions on that. The evidence that marijuana is a gateway drug to trying other drugs, including tobacco, "is limited," the researchers say. But they found "moderate evidence" that there's a link between cannabis use and the development of substance dependence or abuse problems with alcohol, tobacco and illicit drugs. What's more, the evidence suggests that initiating marijuana use at a younger age, the researchers say, "increases the likelihood of developing dependency, which can affect academic performance and social interactions."

Comment: Rick's article may strike some as being opinionated, but if one reads closely, you will see that his point of view is constructed around something unique in this on-going discussion- factual information. The Denali buffer issue should not be made into a political issue (even though it has been already). It is an ecological issue, and if the Park Service and the Alaska Department of Fish and Game want a healthy intact ecosystem in Denali National Park, which is in the best interest of both agencies, as well as that of all Alaskans, then a conservation easement protecting wolves is necessary. Ensuring that we protect diversity and wildness within Denali National Park is not only important economically, and ecologically, it is important in preserving our identities as Alaskans. Denali National Park epitomizes what makes Alaska great, and wolves are a part of that. 
Bravo Rick
